title: Text Title
body:
Myt PLC is a publicly held multinational corporation based in the USA that manufactures non-alcoholic beverages. From humble beginnings with a single root beer, Myt has grown rapidly, now boasting over 30 drinks sold globally. Recent strategic moves include acquiring:

  • Lotssa Coffee (LC) – a global coffee shop chain

  • Honest Water (HW) – a bottled water manufacturer

As Myt navigates consumer health concerns and environmental pressures, it has announced ambitions to:

  • Enter the healthy snacks market

  • Modernise factories to become more sustainable

  • Improve CSR

  • Explore the use of avatars in advertising

  • Reduce sugar and caffeine levels in its drinks

title: Text Title
body:
Effective decision-making is the backbone of strong business strategy — especially in a complex, fast-moving global company like Myt PLC. The tools you've explored in this module — SWOT Analysis, Decision Trees, Force Field Analysis, Porter’s Generic Strategies, and Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions — help transform raw information into structured, strategic thinking.


These tools not only help businesses weigh risks and opportunities, but also allow you, as a business student, to justify your answers with logical, evidence-based reasoning. Whether you're writing Paper 1 essays, preparing for internal assessments, or thinking like a real-world manager, applying these tools correctly can set your work apart.


Remember:

  • Use SWOT to assess internal and external factors.

  • Apply Decision Trees to forecast financial outcomes.

  • Use Force Field Analysis (HL only) to evaluate the strength of change drivers.

  • Apply Porter’s Strategies (HL only) to evaluate competitive positioning.

  • Use Hofstede’s Dimensions (HL only) to tailor strategies across cultures.


Now that you’ve mastered these tools, it's time to move on to our Planning Tools.

title: Text Title
body:
A business plan is a written document that outlines a company’s goals and the strategy it will use to achieve them. It includes operational, financial, and marketing plans, and is typically used to:

  • Attract investors or secure loans

  • Guide internal decision-making

  • Clarify direction for teams and stakeholders

Critical Path Analysis (CPA) is a project planning technique used to identify the sequence of tasks that determine the shortest time a project can be completed. It helps managers:

  • Find the critical path — the longest path through dependent tasks

  • Identify float/slack time — tasks that can be delayed without affecting overall project completion

  • Allocate resources more efficiently

  • Minimise delays and cost overruns

title: Text Title
body: The Boston Consulting Group (BCG) Matrix is a tool that helps businesses evaluate their product portfolio by analysing market share and market growth. It helps determine where to allocate resources and whether to invest, hold, or divest.

title: Text Narrative Title

_items.title: Strategic Implications for Stars
_items.body:
These are the future leaders of the business. They require significant investment to maintain their position and support further growth. Over time, if the market matures, Stars can become Cash Cows.

   Strategy: Invest heavily, promote, expand market share.

_items.title: Strategic Implications for Cash Cows
_items.body:
These are mature, well-established products that generate steady profits but don’t require much reinvestment. They should be “milked” for cash to fund Stars and Question Marks.

   Strategy: Maximise efficiency, reduce costs, maintain market share, avoid major investment.

_items.title: Strategic Implications for Question Marks
_items.body:
These are uncertain opportunities. They operate in fast-growing markets but currently hold a small market share. Businesses must decide whether to invest and grow them into Stars or divest if they don't show potential.

   Strategy: Analyse performance closely, test marketing, consider repositioning.

_items.title: Strategic Implications for Dogs
_items.body:
These products typically offer low returns and have limited future potential. They may tie up resources that could be better used elsewhere. Sometimes worth keeping for strategic reasons (e.g., niche audience), but often considered for removal.

   Strategy: Divest, discontinue, or reposition if they can serve a small profitable segment.

title: Matching Title

_items.text: Myt’s flagship Root Beer continues to generate steady profits after decades on the market. Although the overall soft drink market is growing slowly, Root Beer maintains a dominant market share, especially among nostalgic and long-time consumers. It doesn’t require major promotional spending anymore, and its production costs are relatively low.

Honest Water, acquired recently, is part of a rapidly growing bottled water market. Its branding around health and sustainability resonates well with young consumers, and it has quickly gained a significant market share in multiple regions. Myt is investing heavily to scale production and expand internationally.

Myt recently launched an AI-personalised fitness drink that connects to an app offering health insights. It’s in a fast-growing market for tech-enabled health products, but Myt’s share is still small due to limited brand awareness and competition from tech-focused startups. The product shows promise but needs strategic decisions on whether to expand or pull back.

Myt Frothy, a niche flavoured drink aimed at Gen Z gamers, launched three years ago but failed to gain traction. Sales have steadily declined, and the energy drink market it competes in is now saturated. The product has been quietly discontinued in some regions due to poor performance and lack of profitability.

In this section, you’ve explored a range of strategic planning tools that help businesses like Myt PLC make informed, forward-thinking decisions. These tools don’t just help plan — they help prioritise, forecast, and focus resources where they’re most effective.


You’ve learned how to:


  • Structure business ideas using a Business Plan

  • Visualise timelines and responsibilities with a Gantt Chart

  • Identify critical tasks and float time using Critical Path Analysis (HL only)

  • Assess growth strategies using the Ansoff Matrix

  • Evaluate a product portfolio with the BCG Matrix


Each tool offers a unique perspective — whether it's choosing the right markets to enter, understanding which products to invest in, or managing time-sensitive projects efficiently.


Most importantly, you’ve learned how to apply these tools to real-world scenarios, like Myt PLC’s expansion into healthy snacks or sustainable operations. In Paper 1, your ability to select and apply the right planning tool will make your answers more strategic, insightful, and organised.

title: Text Title

In Paper 1, you’ll often be asked to analyse business actions and propose strategic responses. Situational tools help you:


  • Assess the external environment Myt is responding to (STEEPLE)

  • Justify pricing and product decisions using Contribution Analysis

  • Interpret performance data or customer trends with statistics

  • Predict outcomes with quantitative models (HL)

  • Evaluate ethical or sustainability goals, especially in global markets

title: Text Title
body:
Situational tools help businesses analyse and respond to their current environment, based on internal conditions and external influences. Unlike planning or decision-making tools that help forecast or evaluate options, situational tools focus on understanding the context a business is operating in right now.

These tools are especially useful when:

  • A business is launching a new product

  • Responding to external challenges (e.g. regulations, social trends)

  • Evaluating financial health or resource availability

For a global business like Myt PLC, situational tools are critical for making informed decisions that reflect the market realities in each region they operate in.

title: Text Title
body:
Contribution Analysis is a tool used to determine how much money a product contributes to covering fixed costs and generating profit, after deducting variable costs.


The key formula is:


Contribution per unit = Selling Price per Unit − Variable Cost per Unit


It helps businesses decide:

  • Whether to continue selling a product

  • What price to set

  • How many units must be sold to break even

Linear Regression is a quantitative forecasting method used to examine the relationship between two variables — usually one independent (predictor) and one dependent (outcome). It’s commonly used in business to predict future trends, like sales, based on factors such as advertising spend, pricing, or social media engagement.


The most common form of graph to show linear regression is a scatter plot. On a Paper 1 or Paper 2 you may be asked to draw a scatter plot with a line of best fit.

title: Text Title
body:
A circular business model is a sustainability-focused approach that aims to reduce waste and maximise resource efficiency by designing products and systems that are regenerative by design.


Unlike traditional “linear” models (take → make → use → dispose), circular models aim to:


  • Design out waste

  • Keep products and materials in use for as long as possible

  • Use renewable or biodegradable materials

  • Reuse, refurbish, repair, or recycle products
